title: 108_s2643
content: The Act may be cited as the "Cigarette Fire Safety Act of 2004". It includes findings related to fire safety. The Congress finds that cigarette ignited fires are the leading cause of fire deaths in the United States, resulting in numerous casualties and property damage. Former Member of Congress Joseph Moakley played a significant role in advocating for fire safety standards through legislative acts. The Congress finds cigarette fires are a major cause of fire deaths in the US. Legislation is needed to establish a cigarette fire safety standard, as the cost of not having one is $4.6 billion annually. The Consumer Product Safety Commission should oversee the implementation of this standard. The Congress finds cigarette fires are a major cause of fire deaths in the US. The Consumer Product Safety Commission should oversee the implementation of this standard. SEC. 3. CIGARETTE FIRE SAFETY STANDARD. The Commission must establish fire safety standards for cigarettes within 18 months of the Act's enactment, based on the New York standard. Special testing may be required for cigarettes with unique characteristics. The Commission may approve a manufacturer's proposed test method and performance standard for cigarettes that cannot be tested according to the Commission's method. The term "Commission" refers to the Consumer Product Safety Commission. The rule and any modifications must be prescribed in accordance with section 553 of title 5, United States Code. The Commission may modify the testing methodology under section 553 of title 5, United States Code, to enhance fire safety standards. The Commission can modify fire safety standards if technically feasible and beneficial. Federal laws do not apply to the promulgation of the rule required for the modification. The Commission can modify fire safety standards under specific federal laws, including the Consumer Product Safety Act and the Small Business Regulatory Enforcement Fairness Act. The effective date of the rule must be specified within 24 months. The fire safety standard must have an effective date within 24 months of the enactment of the Act. It will be treated as a consumer product safety standard under the Consumer Product Safety Act, with cigarettes also considered consumer products for the purposes of the Act. SEC. 4. PREEMPTION. This Act and any cigarette fire safety standard established may not preempt or affect state laws with more stringent standards. Private remedies under the Consumer Product Safety Act apply. SEC. 5. SCOPE OF JURISDICTION. The Commission has no jurisdiction over tobacco or tobacco products. SEC. 6. AUTHORIZATION OF APPROPRIATIONS. Authorization of Appropriations: $2,000,000 is authorized to the Consumer Product Safety Commission for fiscal year 2005. Amounts remain available until expended.
